meta.description: Disallow comparisons where both sides are exactly the same

content.introduction:
Disallow comparisons where both sides are exactly the same
Table of ContentsRule DetailsKnown LimitationsVersionResources
Comparing a variable against itself is usually an error, either a typo or refactoring error. It is confusing to the reader and may potentially introduce a runtime error.
The only time you would compare a variable against itself is when you are testing forNaN. However, it is far more appropriate to usetypeof x === 'number' && isNaN(x)or theNumber.isNaN ES2015 functionfor that use case rather than leaving the reader of the code to determine the intent of self comparison.
